Narrator is the default screen reader for Windows. Enable it by going to Start > Settings > Ease of Access and toggle Narrator On. (<https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/complete-guide-to-narrator-e4397a0d-ef4f-b386-d8ae-c172f109bdb1|Complete guide to Narrator>)
Turn on VoiceOver by pressing Command-F5 on your Mac keyboard. (<https://www.apple.com/voiceover/info/guide/_1124.html|Learning VoiceOver Basics>)

White Cane Safety Day is a national observance in the United States, celebrated on October 15 of each year since 1964. The date is set aside to celebrate the achievements of people who are blind or visually impaired and the important symbol of blindness and tool of independence, :probing_cane: the white cane.
Don't forget to provide captions for your recorded meetings and videos. (<https://www.w3.org/WAI/perspective-videos/captions|Learn more>).

Version 1.0 of WCAG focused heavily on HTML techniques. WCAG 2 takes a different approach, introducing four user-centered principles of accessibility, P.O.U.R (Perceivable, Operable, Understandable, and Robust). By emphasizing principles rather than techniques, developers should approach the process conceptually. (<https://webaim.org/articles/pour/|Constructing a POUR Website>)

Worldwide, there are approximately (<https://www.colourblindawareness.org/colour-blindness/|300 million people>) with colour blindness, almost the same number of people as the entire population of the USA! Use a color contrast analyzer while developing your designs. (<https://www.uxpin.com/studio/blog/evaluate-design-color-contrast|Best Ways to Evaluate Your Design for Color Contrast>)
Globally, at least 2.2 billion people have a near or distance vision impairment. (<https://www.who.int/en/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/blindness-and-visual-impairment|WHO>)

Provide text alternatives for any non-text content so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as large print, braille, speech, symbols or simpler language. (<https://www.w3.org/TR/UNDERSTANDING-WCAG20/text-equiv.html#text-equiv|WCAG 2.0 Guideline 1.1>)

Colors play a central role in data visualization. But what if your readers are color blind? Design charts with a color blind friendly palette and use patterns and textures. (<https://venngage.com/blog/color-blind-friendly-palette/#4|More tips>)
